results.abstract: Article on work of TriBeCa photographer Arne Svenson who, after much sleuthing and detective work on Internet and elsewhere, has solved riddle of snapshots he received from friend portraying parrots and cockatoos dressed in costumes and staged in miniature theater sets with handmade props; Alba Ballard of Huntington, NY, who died in 1994, is subject of Svenson's new book Mrs Ballard's Birds, which includes her photographs; photos (M)

headline.main: A Dreamer and Her Parrot-Shtick Method

results.snippet: Behind Arne Svenson's book "Mrs. Ballard's Birds" lies a fascinating search for an elusive bird trainer and her bizarre menagerie.
results.lead_paragraph: In 1992, Elizabeth Taylor's daughter Liza Todd Tivey gave a curious package to her friend Arne Svenson, a TriBeCa photographer with a taste for photographic arcana. The small box held several dozen snapshots a fan had sent to Ms. Taylor sometime back in the 1970's. The accompanying letter had been lost, the fan's name long forgotten. Enriching the mystery were the photographs themselves: bizarre shots of parrots and cockatoos dressed in tiny people costumes, staged in miniature theater sets with handmade props. In one, a pair of parrots on little motorcycles recreated an iconic image from ''Easy Rider.'' In another, a cockatoo in a gold jacket posed with what was literally a baby grand piano, evoking Liberace. There were parrots playing baseball, parrots boxing, parrots portraying Bonnie and Clyde and Sonny and Cher. Parrots dressed up as Patton, Custer, Madame Butterfly and, in a strange act of cross-species cross-dressing, a parrot Mickey Mouse.

results.abstract: Interesting fixtures combine with natural light to set off design touches in Paris apartment; photos (M)
results.snippet: Alexandre de Betak's Paris apartment is a cool, well-lighted place.
results.lead_paragraph: Each afternoon , usually around 4, the sun beams directly onto the disco ball perched on the living room mantel of Alexandre de Betak's Paris apartment, producing a spray of shimmying lights. ''It's the happy hour chez Betak-Marnay,'' says Betak, who recently transformed what he describes as ''a typical bourgeois apartment'' in the 16th Arrondissement into a colorful aerie for himself; his wife, the model and actress Audrey Marnay; and their two young sons, Amaël and Aidyn. But spend some time chez Betak-Marnay, and you quickly realize that there is a never a dim moment. While the apartment receives a fair amount of natural light, de Betak has set every corner of every room ablaze. Lights crowd the shelves, the tables, the floor -- every outlet is a snarl of electrical cords. (And yes, the renovation included rewiring.) Some of the lights are sculptures, like the Gianfranco Fini composition of Plexiglass rods jutting through a black field, or ''La Luna,'' Paola Pagani and Carlo Pellegrini's bisected sphere. Others are toys, like the marshmallowy Barbapapa that glows cheerfully in the boys' room; still others are relics of disco days past. ''When I was a teenager, we would have these boum parties,'' says de Betak, who grew up attending the popular dance gigs in Paris. He points to a cluster of multicolored headlights:

results.abstract: Jon Pareles reviews performance of Duran Duran at Madison Square Garden; photo (M)

headline.main: Nostalgia for the Skinny Tie as Duran Duran Returns

results.snippet: While the fans applauded songs from Duran Duran's new album, it was the oldies that kept the audience on its feet Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden.
results.lead_paragraph: You don't have to be a teenager to scream like one. That was clear when Duran Duran played the last show of its current American tour on Wednesday at Madison Square Garden. Happy screeches from fans who clearly remembered the band from its 1980's heyday greeted the five members as they arrived onstage in the dark and stood side by side, fully confident that they'd be illuminated by camera flashes. They were. It's a semi-reunion for Duran Duran, whose hitmaking lineup ruptured in 1985 when its drummer, Roger Taylor, and its guitarist, Andy Taylor, left the band. The singer Simon LeBon, the keyboardist Nick Rhodes and the bassist John Taylor (none of the Taylors are related) kept making Duran Duran albums, with diminishing returns, until the two other Taylors returned in 2003.

headline.main: To Return Shuttle to Space, NASA Calls on Cool Leader

results.snippet: Col. Eileen M. Collins is scheduled to lead the first space shuttle flight since the Columbia disaster.

byline.original: By JOHN SCHWARTZ; Michelle York contributed reporting from Elmira, N.Y., for this article

results.lead_paragraph: There was a glitch in the sim. During a simulated landing on April 6, the altimeter reading had the space shuttle cruising on approach to the runway at 4,000 feet below sea level. Sims are serious business: they are carefully designed tests that throw realistic problems at crews and build the reflexes that could save lives. The faulty altimeter reading was an error that could have ruined the exercise. Without any sign of frustration or irritation, but with a large dose of astronaut-issue composure, Col. Eileen M. Collins, the shuttle's commander, said simply, ''That was a brand-new one,'' and completed the landing sequence.

results.snippet: At Least 20 Are Killed In Latest Violence in Iraq  A group of Sunni Arab kidnappers threatened to kill their Shiite hostages unless all Shiites agree to evacuate a town south of Baghdad. In the capital and other parts of the country, a wave of...
results.lead_paragraph: At Least 20 Are Killed In Latest Violence in Iraq A group of Sunni Arab kidnappers threatened to kill their Shiite hostages unless all Shiites agree to evacuate a town south of Baghdad. In the capital and other parts of the country, a wave of suicide bombings and shootings left at least 20 people dead, including 13 Iraqis killed in a bombing at a Baquba restaurant. PAGE 15 More Instability in Ecuador President Lucio Gutiérrez of Ecuador dissolved the Supreme Court and declared a state of emergency in the capital, enabling the government to curb civil liberties and quell demonstrations. PAGE 10 The Nice Astronaut There is a consensus opinion about Col. Eileen M. Collins, the first female space shuttle pilot, who is scheduled next month to be the commander of the first shuttle mission since the Columbia disaster in 2003. She is unassuming, capable and, well, nice. results.abstract: Editorial says Bush administration's choice to lead NASA, Michael Griffin, at his confirmation hearings, showed independence of mind and willingness to abandon past NASA decisions that look increasingly myopic, such as decision to abandon planned astronaut servicing mission to extend life of Hubble Space Telescope; says he looks eminently qualified to head agency

headline.main: A New Leader's Thoughts on NASA

results.snippet: There is little doubt that the agency needs a firm hand at the top, and with his experience, the newly-elected Michael Griffin looks eminently qualified.
results.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration's choice to lead the National Aeronautics and Space Administration -- Michael Griffin -- sailed through the confirmation process last week. In hearings before the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation, only Senator George Allen of Virginia was churlish enough to raise concerns about cuts in the aeronautics budget that could lead to job losses in his home state. The other members seemed intent on whisking Dr. Griffin through as fast as possible so that he could take the helm of the space agency as it prepares to resume shuttle flights. There is little doubt that the agency needs a firm hand at the top as it struggles to rebound from the Columbia tragedy, and Dr. Griffin, who has held a variety of jobs in the aerospace industry, looks eminently qualified.

results.abstract: In this lesson, students learn about NASA's next flight commander, Colonel Eileen M. Collins. They then learn about other extraordinary American women in various fields and create biographies celebrating their achievements.
results.snippet: In this lesson, students learn about NASA's next flight commander, Colonel Eileen M. Collins. They then learn about other extraordinary American women in various fields and create biographies celebrating their achievements.

byline.original: By KRISTEN TEPFENHARDT and BRIDGET ANDERSON

results.abstract: NASA throws open gates of its 1,600-acre campus at Johnson Space Center in Houston, restoring festive annual tradition and offering close-up look at business of sending men and women into the cosmos (Letter from Clear Lake); photos (M)

headline.main: Astronauts at the Mall, and Rocket Scientists at the Bar

results.snippet: NASA threw open the gates of the Johnson Space Center, offering a close-up look at the business of sending men and women into the cosmos.
results.lead_paragraph: It was a little soon to party the first space shuttle blastoff since the Columbia accident is not until May 22 at the earliest -- but it was high time to have the neighbors over. So on Saturday, for the first time since the terrorist attacks of 2001, NASA threw open the gates of its 1,600-acre campus at the Johnson Space Center here in Clear Lake, restoring a festive annual tradition and offering a close-up look at the business of sending men and women into the cosmos. With security tight, NASA did little to publicize the event, but some 30,000 visitors streamed in, a testament to close ties in this community, a onetime sailing village long since swallowed up by Houston, where astronauts are the folks you see shopping at the Baybrook Mall or hoisting one at the Outpost after work.

results.abstract: Russian Soyuz capsule bumps down on Kazakh steppe early Apr 25, bringing Russian, an American and an Italian astronaut safely back to Earth from International Space Station (S)
results.snippet: A Russian Soyuz capsule bumped down on the Kazakh steppe, bringing a Russian, an American and an Italian astronaut safely back to Earth.
results.lead_paragraph: A Russian Soyuz capsule bumped down on the Kazakh steppe early on Monday, bringing a Russian, an American and an Italian astronaut safely back to Earth from the International Space Station. The landing, under a nearly full moon two hours before daybreak, was complicated by flooding on the steppe that covers much of this Central Asian state.
